Authors: Katarzyna Szczepanska, Jacek Urbaniak, Lucyna Sliwa
Title:
Taxonomic recognition of some species-level lineages 2
circumscribed in nominal Rhizoplaca subdiscrepans 3 s. lat.
(Lecanoraceae, Ascomycota)
Keywords:
Lichenized fungi, Rhizoplaca, cryptic species, phylogeny,
taxonomy, geographical distribution, biodiversity
Abstract:
Rhizoplaca subdiscrepans (Nyl.) R. Sant. is a saxicolous,
placodioid lichen species considered as a worldwide distributed and
occurring in warm-temperate to boreal-arctic areas in Asia, Europa and
North America (Ryan 2001). However, recent studies revealed R.
subdiscrepans is a polyphyletic taxon including five cryptic
species-level lineages defined as ‘subd A, B, C, D, E’ (Leavitt et
al. 2016). During research focused on diversity of saxicolous lichens in
mountain area of southern Poland some interesting representatives of the
genus Rhizoplaca have been found. To identify those samples multiple
analyses of reference herbarium material from Europe, North and South
America and Asia were made. In the phylogenetic studies we have found
our specimens cluster with members of a genetic lineage ‘subd E’ as
delimited by Leavitt et al. (2016). Complex analyses of the group of
species lead us to a conclusion the lineage may represents R.
subdiscrepans in the strict sense, which seems European taxon with
limited geographical distribution and specific habitat preferences. What
is more, some of the recently defined species candidates within R.
subdiscrapans s.l. (subd D and subd A) may be assigned to a previously
well known species of Rhizoplaca genus, described in the second half of
the 20th century, respectively  Rhizoplaca opiniconensis (Brodo)
Leavitt, Zhao Xin & Lumbsch and Rhizoplaca phaedrophthalma (Poelt)
Leavitt, Zhao Xin & Lumbsch. Although the mentioned species
candidates were considered cryptic, we have found their representatives
indicate some subtle differences in morphology and chemistry, as well as
variations concerning habitats requirements and geographical
distribution. Additionally we have found Lecanora pseudomellea B.D. Ryan
is a strongly supported monophyletic lineage within Rhizoplaca and
therefore we propose appropriate new combination for the species.
